verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Peter, an [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]apostle of Jesus Christ, to the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]sojourners of the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]dispersion of [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]Pontus, [xref]f[/xref]Galatia, Cappadocia, [xref]g[/xref]Asia, and [xref]h[/xref]Bithynia,
verse.note: The name Peter denotes Peter's regenerated and spiritual man, whereas the name Simon denotes his natural man by birth ([link]John 1:42[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:17-18[/link]).
An apostle to the Jews ([link]Gal. 2:8[/link]).

Or, pilgrims. Strictly, in this book this term refers to the Jewish believers who were pilgrims, foreigners, dispersed in the Gentile world ([link]2:11-12[/link]). However, the principle of being sojourners could be applied to all believers, both Jewish and Gentile, because all are heavenly sojourners, sojourning as foreigners on this earth. These sojourners are God's elect, chosen by God out of the human race, out of all the nations ([link]Rev. 5:9-10[/link]), according to His foreknowledge ([link]v. 2[/link]).

A term familiar to all the Jews scattered among the nations, indicating that this Epistle was written to the Jewish believers. It is from the Greek word that means [i]to scatter or spread abroad;[/i] its root means [i]to sow.[/i] This implies that the scattered Jews were sown as seeds among the Gentiles.
All five provinces mentioned here were in Asia Minor, between the Black Sea and the Mediterranean.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Chosen [note]2[/note]according to the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]foreknowledge of God the Father [note]4[/note]in the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]sanctification of the Spirit [note]6[/note]unto the [note]7[/note][xref]d[/xref]obedience and [note]8[/note][xref]e[/xref]sprinkling of the [note]9[/note]blood of Jesus Christ: [note]10[/note]Grace to you and [note]11[/note]peace be [note]12[/note][xref]f[/xref]multiplied.
verse.note: Both of Peter's Epistles ([link]2 Pet. 3:1[/link]) are concerned with the government of God. God's government is universal and deals with all His creatures that He may have a clean and pure universe ([link]2 Pet. 3:13[/link]) in order to express Himself. In the New Testament age this dealing begins from His chosen people, His elect, His own household ([link]4:17[/link]), and especially from His chosen sojourners who are dispersed and are sojourning among the nations, the Gentiles, as His testimony. Hence, these two books emphasize the believers' being chosen ([link]2:9[/link]; [link]5:13[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:10[/link]). As God's chosen race, God's choice, God's particular possession, the dispersed and chosen sojourners need to see that they are under God's governmental dealing for a positive purpose, regardless of the situation and environment they are in. Anything and everything that happens to them, whether persecution or any other kind of trial or suffering ([link]v. 6[/link]; [link]5:9[/link]), is just a part of God's precious governmental dealing. Such a vision will perfect, establish, strengthen, and ground them ([link]5:10[/link]) that they may grow in grace ([link]2 Pet. 3:18[/link]).

Here, the divine economy through the operation of the Trinity of the Godhead for the believers' participation in the Triune God is unveiled. God the Father's selection is the initiation; God the Spirit's sanctification carries out the selection of God the Father; and God the Son's redemption, signified by the sprinkling of His blood, is the completion. Through these steps the believers have been selected, sanctified, and redeemed to enter into the enjoyment of the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — into whom they have been baptized ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]) and whose virtues they are enjoying ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]).
God chose us before the foundation of the world, in eternity past ([link]Eph. 1:4[/link]). Hence, the divine foreknowledge was exercised.

I.e., by the sanctification of the Spirit. This denotes that God the Father's selection is applied to and carried out in God's chosen ones in and by the sanctification of the Spirit, which means that the Spirit sanctifies man by causing him to repent unto God, thus making him a chosen one of God.

Here the sanctification of the Spirit is not the sanctification of the Spirit that comes after justification through the redemption of Christ (the latter sanctification is revealed in [link]Rom. 6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]). Here the sanctification of the Spirit, as the main emphasis in this chapter, an emphasis on holiness ([link]vv. 15-16[/link]), comes before obedience to Christ and faith in His redemption, i.e., before justification through Christ's redemption ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]), indicating that the believers' obedience unto faith in Christ results from the Spirit's sanctifying work. The Spirit's sanctification in its various aspects is revealed in an all-inclusive way in [link]2 Thes. 2:13[/link], and its goal is that God's chosen people may obtain God's full salvation. God's full salvation is carried out in the sphere of the Spirit's sanctification.

Three different prepositions are used in relation to the three steps taken by the Triune God to bring His elect into participation in His full salvation: [i]according to[/i] denotes the ground, the base; [i]in,[/i] the sphere; and [i]unto,[/i] the end, the result. The believers' obedience of faith ([link]Rom. 1:5[/link]; [link]16:26[/link]) in the redemption of Christ and the applying to them of the sprinkling of the blood are the result of the Spirit's sanctification, which is based on God the Father's selection.

The New Testament dispensation has the blood of Jesus Christ. That blood is in contrast to the blood of animals, which the Old Testament dispensation had. The Jewish believers were familiar with the obedience and sprinkling of the blood of animals under the Old Testament dispensation, but now they had to realize that the dispensation had been changed and that under the New Testament dispensation the law of Moses and the blood of animals had been replaced by the person of Christ and the blood of Christ. The result of such a realization is that the believers obey Jesus Christ and are sprinkled by His blood.

In typology the sprinkling of the expiating blood ushered the sprinkled people into the old covenant ([link]Exo. 24:6-8[/link]). Likewise, the sprinkling of Christ's redeeming blood brings the sprinkled believers into the blessing of the new covenant, that is, into the full enjoyment of the Triune God ([link]Heb. 9:13-14[/link]). This is a striking mark that separates the sprinkled people from the common people, who are without God.
The blood for sprinkling denotes redemption. See [link]vv. 18-19[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].

Multiplied grace corresponds with varied grace ([link]4:10[/link]) and all grace ([link]5:10[/link]). The believers have received the initial grace, yet this grace needs to be multiplied in them that they may participate in all grace.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed be the [note]2[/note]God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who according to His great [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]mercy has [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]regenerated us [note]5[/note]unto a [note]6[/note]living [xref]d[/xref]hope [note]7[/note]through the [xref]e[/xref]resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].
See notes [link book="Eph." chapter="1"]3[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].
See note [link]13[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Tim. 1[/link].

Regeneration, like redemption and justification, is an aspect of God's full salvation. Redemption and justification solve our problem with God and reconcile us to God; regeneration enlivens us with God's life, bringing us into a relationship of life, an organic union, with God. Hence, regeneration issues and results in a living hope. Such regeneration is accomplished through the resurrection of Christ from the dead. "The resurrection of Christ, bringing in life and the gift of the life-giving Spirit, is that which potentiates the new birth unto a living hope" (Alford).
Issuing in, resulting in, with a view to.

A hope for the future in our sojourning today — not a hope of objective things but a hope of life, even eternal life, with all the endless divine blessings. Such a hope should cause us to set our hope perfectly on the coming grace ([link]v. 13[/link]).[br][br]The living hope, the hope of life, brought to the regenerated believers through regeneration, can be likened to the various expectations for the future brought to parents through the birth of a newborn babe; all such expectations hinge on the life of the newborn child. Likewise, the life that we, the believers, have received through regeneration enables us to have a hope, with numerous aspects, for this age, for the coming age, and for eternity. In this age we have the hope of growing in life, of maturing, of manifesting our gifts, of exercising our functions, of being transformed, of overcoming, of being redeemed in our body, and of entering into glory. In the coming age we have the hope of entering into the kingdom, of reigning with the Lord, and of enjoying the blessings of the eternal life in the manifestation of the kingdom of the heavens. In eternity we have the hope of being in the New Jerusalem, where we will participate fully in the consummated blessings of the eternal life in its ultimate manifestation in eternity. This living hope, the hope of life, hinges on the eternal life, which we received through regeneration. Only the divine life can enable us to grow in the divine life until we grow into the reality of the hope that is brought to us by that life. Thus we will obtain the various blessings mentioned above as our inheritance, which is incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading and is kept for eternity ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]).

When Christ was resurrected, we, His believers, were all included in Him. Hence, we were resurrected with Him ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]). In His resurrection He imparted the divine life into us and made us the same as He is (see note [link]17[sup]3[/sup] in John 20[/link]). This is the basic factor of our regeneration.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Unto an [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]inheritance, [note]3[/note]incorruptible and undefiled and [xref]b[/xref]unfading, [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]kept in the heavens for you,
verse.note: [i]Unto an inheritance[/i] here is in apposition to [i]unto a living hope[/i] in [link]v. 3[/link]. The living hope, resulting from regeneration, is our expectation of the coming blessing; the inheritance is the fulfillment of our hope in the coming age and in eternity.

See notes [link]32[sup]3[/sup] in Acts 20[/link] and [link]18[sup]6[/sup] in Acts 26[/link]. The inheritance here comprises the coming salvation of our souls ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]9[/link]), the grace to be received at the revelation of the Lord ([link]v. 13[/link]), the glory to be revealed ([link]5:1[/link]), the unfading crown of glory ([link]5:4[/link]), and the eternal glory ([link]5:10[/link]). All these items of our eternal inheritance are related to the divine life, which we received through regeneration and which we are experiencing and enjoying throughout our entire Christian life. "This inheritance is the full possession of that, which was promised to Abraham and all believers ([link]Gen. 12:3[/link]; see [link]Gal. 3:6[/link] ff.), an inheritance, as much higher than that which fell to the children of Israel in the possession of Canaan, as the sonship of the regenerate, who have already received the promise of the Spirit through faith as a pledge of their inheritance, is higher than the sonship of Israel: compare [link]Gal. 3:18[/link], [link]29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:9[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:15[/link]" (Wiesinger, quoted by Alford).

Incorruptible in substance, indestructible, not decaying; undefiled in purity, unstained; unfading in beauty and glory, not withering. These are the excelling qualities of our eternal inheritance in life. These qualities should be related to the Divine Trinity: [i]incorruptible[/i] relates to the nature of the Father, which is like gold; [i]undefiled,[/i] to the condition preserved by the Spirit's sanctifying work; and [i]unfading,[/i] to the glorious expression of the Son.
Kept as the result of being guarded.

verse.text: Who are being [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]guarded [note]2[/note]by the power of God [note]3[/note]through faith [note]4[/note]unto a [note]5[/note]salvation ready to be [xref]b[/xref]revealed at the [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]last time;
verse.note: A military term; lit., garrisoned.
Lit., in. In virtue of; hence, by.
The power of God is the cause of our being guarded. Secondarily, faith is the means through which the power of God becomes effective in guarding us.
Three prepositions are used here concerning our coming salvation: [i]by, through,[/i] and [i]unto. By[/i] refers to the cause, [i]through[/i] to the means, and [i]unto[/i] to the result.

Not salvation from eternal perdition but the salvation of our souls from the dispensational punishment of the Lord's governmental dealing ([link]v. 9[/link] and note 2). The full salvation of the Triune God is in three stages and comprises many items:[br][br](1) The initial stage, the stage of regeneration, which is composed of redemption, sanctification (positional — [link]v. 2[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]), justification, reconciliation, and regeneration. In this stage God justified us through the redemption of Christ ([link]Rom. 3:24-26[/link]) and regenerated us in our spirit with His life by His Spirit ([link]John 3:3-6[/link]). Thus we received God's eternal salvation ([link]Heb. 5:9[/link]) and His eternal life ([link]John 3:15[/link]) and became His children ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]), who shall not perish forever ([link]John 10:28-29[/link]). This initial salvation has saved us from God's condemnation and from eternal perdition ([link]John 3:18[/link], [link]16[/link]).[br][br](2) The progressing stage, the stage of transformation, which is composed of freedom from sin, sanctification (mainly dispositional — [link]Rom. 6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]), growth in life, transformation, building up, and maturing. In this stage God is freeing us from the dominion of indwelling sin — the law of sin and of death — by the law of the Spirit of life, through the subjective working of the effectiveness of the death of Christ in us ([link]Rom. 6:6-7[/link]; [link]7:16-20[/link]; [link]8:2[/link]); sanctifying us by His Holy Spirit ([link]Rom. 15:16[/link]), with His holy nature, through His discipline ([link]Heb. 12:10[/link]) and His judgment in His own house ([link]4:17[/link]); causing us to grow in His life ([link]1 Cor. 3:6-7[/link]); transforming us by renewing the inward parts of our soul by the life-giving Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link], [link]17-18[/link]; [link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:23[/link]) through the working of all things ([link]Rom. 8:28[/link]); building us together into a spiritual house for His dwelling ([link]2:5[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:22[/link]); and maturing us in His life ([link]Rev. 14:15[/link] and notes) for the completion of His full salvation. In this way we are being delivered from the power of sin, the world, the flesh, self, the soul (the natural life), and individualism into maturity in the divine life for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose.[br][br](3) The completing stage, the stage of glorification, which is composed of the redemption (transfiguration) of our body, conformity to the Lord, glorification, the inheritance of God's kingdom, participation in Christ's kingship, and the topmost enjoyment of the Lord. In this stage God will redeem our fallen and corrupted body ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]) by transfiguring it into the body of Christ's glory ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]); conform us to the glorious image of His firstborn Son ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]), making us wholly and absolutely like Him in our regenerated spirit, transformed soul, and transfigured body; and glorify us ([link]Rom. 8:30[/link]), immersing us in His glory ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]) that we may enter into His heavenly kingdom ([link]2 Tim. 4:18[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:11[/link]), into which He has called us ([link]1 Thes. 2:12[/link]), and inherit it as the topmost portion of His blessing ([link]James 2:5[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:21[/link]) — even that we may reign with Christ as His co-kings, participating in His kingship over the nations ([link]2 Tim. 2:12[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]2:26-27[/link]; [link]12:5[/link]) and sharing His royal, kingly joy in His divine government ([link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). In this way our body will be freed from the slavery of corruption of the old creation into the freedom of the glory of God's new creation ([link]Rom. 8:21[/link]), and our soul will be delivered out of the realm of trials and sufferings ([link]v. 6[/link]; [link]4:12[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]; [link]5:9[/link]) into a new realm, one that is full of glory ([link]4:13[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]), and will share in and enjoy all that the Triune God is, has, and has accomplished, attained, and obtained. This is the salvation of our souls, the salvation that is ready to be revealed to us at the last time, the grace to be brought to us at the revelation of Christ in glory ([link]v. 13[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:27[/link]; [link]25:31[/link]). This is the end of our faith. The power of God is able to guard us unto this that we may obtain it ([link]v. 9[/link]). We should eagerly expect such a marvelous salvation ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]) and prepare ourselves for its splendid revelation ([link]Rom. 8:19[/link]).
The time of the Lord's coming ([link]v. 7[/link]).

verse.text: In which [note]1[/note][i]time[/i] you [xref]a[/xref]exult, though for a [xref]b[/xref]little while at present, if it must be, you have been made sorrowful by various [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]trials,
verse.note: Referring to the last time, mentioned in [link]v. 5[/link].

Sufferings that become trials to test the quality. The purpose of this book is to establish and strengthen the suffering believers, who have been chosen by God, sanctified from the world unto God by the Spirit, sprinkled by the redeeming blood of Christ, and regenerated by God the Father unto a living hope, unto an inheritance kept in the heavens for them ([link]vv. 1-4[/link]), yet are sojourners still sojourning on this earth ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]2:11[/link]). In their sojourn, sufferings are unavoidable. These are used by God to prove and try the believers' faith ([link]v. 7[/link]), to see whether they will follow Christ in suffering for doing good ([link]2:19-23[/link]; [link]3:14-18[/link]). The sufferings are used to arm them with a mind against the flesh that they may live not in the lusts of men but in the will of God ([link]4:1-2[/link]), that they may share the sufferings of Christ and rejoice at the revelation of His glory ([link]4:12-19[/link]), that they may be witnesses of the sufferings of Christ ([link]5:1[/link]), and that they may be perfected, established, strengthened, and grounded for the eternal glory into which God has called them ([link]5:8-10[/link]). This is wholly under God's government, that He may judge His chosen people ([link]v. 17[/link]), beginning His judgment from His own house ([link]4:17[/link]). Hence, this book can also be considered a book concerning God's government.

verse.text: So that the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]proving of your faith, [note]2[/note]much more [note]3[/note]precious than of gold which perishes though it is [xref]b[/xref]proved by fire, may be found [note]4[/note]unto [xref]c[/xref]praise and [xref]d[/xref]glory and honor at the [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]revelation of Jesus Christ;
verse.note: I.e., testing for approval. It is the trying, the proving, of faith, not the faith itself, that may be found unto praise. (This is like the school's examination of the student's studying: what is found to be approved is the examination, not the student's studying itself.) Of course, the approval of faith comes out of the proper faith. The stress here is not on faith but on the proving of faith by trials that come through sufferings.
[i]Much more precious than of gold[/i]...by fire modifies not [i]your faith[/i] but [i]proving.[/i]

In his two Epistles Peter presents to us five precious things: (1) the precious stone, which is the Lord Himself ([link]2:4[/link], [link]6-7[/link]); (2) the precious blood ([link]v. 19[/link]); (3) the precious promises ([link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]); (4) the precious faith ([link]2 Pet. 1:1[/link]); and (5) the precious proving ([link]v. 7[/link]).
The various trials in [link]v. 6[/link] come upon us so that the proving of our faith will result in praise, glory, and honor at the revelation of the Lord.

The Lord is with us today ([link]Matt. 28:20[/link]), but in a hidden, veiled way. His coming back will be His revelation, when He will be seen openly by all. At that time not only He but also the proving of our faith will be revealed.

verse.text: Whom having not [xref]a[/xref]seen, you [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]love; [note]2[/note]into whom though not seeing [i]Him[/i] at present, yet [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]believing, you [xref]d[/xref]exult with [note]4[/note]joy [i]that is[/i] unspeakable and [note]4[/note]full of glory,
verse.note: It is a wonder and a mystery that the believers love One whom they have not seen.
[i]Into whom[/i] modifies [i]believing.[/i]

We love Him whom we have not seen because of believing, because of the very faith that has been infused into us through our hearing of the living word ([link]Gal. 3:2[/link]). Hence, this faith is under the proving, the trying, mentioned in [link]v. 7[/link].
Joy full of glory is joy immersed in glory; hence, joy that is full of the Lord expressed.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Receiving the end of your faith, the [xref]a[/xref]salvation of your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]souls.
verse.note: According to grammar, this word continues [link]v. 8[/link], but according to fact, it is connected with [link]v. 7[/link]. The proving of our faith being found unto praise, glory, and honor results in the receiving of the end of our faith, that is, the salvation of our souls.

We are of three parts: spirit, soul, and body (see notes [link]23[sup]5[/sup] in 1 Thes. 5[/link] and [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link]). Our spirit was saved through regeneration ([link]John 3:5-6[/link]). Our body will be saved, redeemed, through the coming transfiguration ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:23[/link]). Our soul will be saved through sufferings into the full enjoyment of the Lord at His revelation, His coming back. For this we must deny our soul, our soulish life, with all its pleasures in this age, that we may gain it in the enjoyment of the Lord in the coming age ([link]Matt. 10:37-39[/link]; [link]16:24-27[/link]; [link]Luke 17:30-33[/link]; [link]John 12:25[/link]). At the Lord's revelation, through His judgment seat, some believers will enter into the joy of the Lord ([link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]24:45-46[/link]) and some will suffer in weeping and gnashing of teeth ([link]Matt. 25:30[/link]; [link]24:51[/link]). To enter into the Lord's joy is the salvation of our souls ([link]Heb. 10:39[/link] and note 3). This salvation is more precious than the salvation of the body, which the children of Israel expect to receive.

verse.text: Concerning this salvation the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prophets, who prophesied concerning the [note]2[/note]grace [i]that was to come[/i] unto you, sought and searched diligently,
verse.note: Like the Lord ([link]Luke 24:25-27[/link], [link]44-46[/link]), Peter used the Old Testament prophets to confirm his teaching concerning the New Testament salvation.
A synonym for [i]salvation[/i] in this verse. See note [link]13[sup]4[/sup][/link]. For [i]grace,[/i] see notes [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in John 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Searching into [note]2[/note]what [i]time[/i] or what manner of time the Spirit [note]3[/note]of Christ in them was making clear, testifying beforehand of the [note]4[/note]sufferings [note]5[/note]of Christ and the [note]6[/note]glories after these.
verse.note: The searching of the prophets was the Spirit's pre-application of God's salvation in the Old Testament.

The Old Testament prophets were searching into what time and what manner of time the Spirit in them was making clear concerning Christ's marvelous accomplishment through His sufferings and glories. Eventually, it was revealed to them that they ministered those marvelous things not to themselves but to the New Testament believers ([link]v. 12[/link]).

The highly respected Vaticanus MS omits, [i]of Christ.[/i] This omission fits into the New Testament revelation concerning the Spirit. However, the other authoritative MSS have [i]of Christ[/i] in their text. In the New Testament revelation the Spirit of Christ denotes the Spirit after Christ's resurrection ([link]Rom. 8:9-11[/link]). Before Christ's resurrection, the Spirit who is not only the Spirit of God but the Spirit of Christ was not yet ([link]John 7:39[/link]). The Spirit of Christ is the Spirit of God constituted through and with the death and resurrection of Christ for the application and impartation of Christ's death and resurrection to His believers. Although the constituting of the Spirit of Christ is dispensational — i.e., the Spirit of Christ was constituted dispensationally through and with Christ's death and resurrection in the New Testament time — the function of the Spirit of Christ is eternal, because He is the eternal Spirit ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]). This is like the cross of Christ: as an event, it was accomplished at the time of Christ's death, yet its function is eternal; hence, in the eternal sight of God, Christ was slain from the foundation of the world ([link]Rev. 13:8[/link]). In Old Testament times the Spirit of God, as the Spirit of Christ, made the time and the manner of time concerning Christ's death and resurrection clear to the prophets who were seeking and searching diligently concerning the sufferings and glories of Christ.

Christ first suffered and then entered into glory ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]). We should follow Him in the same steps ([link]4:13[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:17[/link]). The sufferings of Christ, as revealed to the prophets and prophesied by them in [link]Psa. 22:1[/link], [link]6-8[/link], [link]12-18[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:2-10a[/link], [link]12b[/link]; [link]Dan. 9:26[/link]; and [link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]13:6-7[/link], are for the accomplishing of God's redemption, which, on the negative side, has solved all the problems between man and God and terminated the old creation, and, on the positive side, has released the eternal life of God for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose.[br][br]The glories of Christ (see note 6) are for His glorification, which He asked of the Father before His crucifixion ([link]John 17:1[/link]) and which is for the executing of God's New Testament economy for the carrying out of God's eternal purpose. The sufferings of Christ and the glorification of Christ with the glories in different steps — the factors of God's full redemption and salvation — being applied to and experienced by us equal the salvation mentioned in [link]vv. 5[/link], [link]9[/link], and 10. This is what the prophets in the Old Testament sought and searched for diligently, what the Spirit of Christ revealed to them, what the apostles preached in the New Testament by the Holy Spirit, and what the angels long to look into ([link]v. 12[/link]).
Lit., unto. The sufferings that Christ endured were sufferings assigned to Him by God ([link]Isa. 53:10[/link]); hence, they are of Him, belonging to Him.

The glories in different steps: the glory in His resurrection ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]; [link]Acts 3:13[/link]), the glory in His ascension ([link]Acts 2:33[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:9[/link]), the glory in His second coming ([link]Rev. 18:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:31[/link]), and the glory in His reign ([link]2 Tim. 2:12[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]), as revealed in [link]Psa. 16:8-10[/link]; [link]22:21-22[/link]; [link]118:22-24[/link]; [link]110:1[/link], [link]4[/link]; [link]118:26[/link]; [link]Zech. 14:4-5[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]; and [link]Psa. 24:7-10[/link]; [link]72:8-11[/link].

verse.text: To them it was revealed that not to themselves but to you they ministered [note]1[/note]these things, which have now been announced to you through those who [note]2[/note]preached the gospel to you by the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit sent from heaven, which things angels long to [note]3[/note]look into.
verse.note: Referring to the sufferings of Christ and His glories, mentioned in [link]v. 11[/link].
The preaching of the apostles is the Spirit's practical application of God's salvation in the New Testament.

The Greek word portrays one who is stooping and stretching his neck to look at some wonderful sight. This shows how interested the angels are in observing the things concerning Christ for God's salvation. They declared and celebrated the Savior's birth ([link]Luke 2:8-14[/link]), they rejoice over the sinners' repenting to receive salvation ([link]Luke 15:10[/link]), and they are happy to serve those who inherit salvation ([link]Heb. 1:14[/link]; [link]Acts 12:15[/link]; [link]Matt. 18:10[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore [xref]a[/xref]girding up the loins of your mind [i]and[/i] being [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sober, set your [note]3[/note]hope perfectly on the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]grace being brought to you at the [xref]d[/xref]revelation of Jesus Christ.
verse.note: [link]Verses 3-12[/link] are a long sentence of blessing (well speaking) concerning God the Father, disclosing to us His marvelous and excellent salvation, beginning from the regeneration of our spirit ([link]v. 3[/link]) and consummating in the salvation of our soul ([link]v. 9[/link]), accomplished through the sufferings and glories of Christ ([link]v. 11[/link]) and applied to us by the Holy Spirit ([link]v. 12[/link]). Based on this, [link]v. 13[/link] begins an exhortation to those who are participating in the full salvation carried out by the Triune God according to His economy.
Calm and clear in mind, able to realize God's economy in His salvation, as revealed in [link]vv. 3-12[/link], without being disturbed by fear, anxiety, or any care.
The living hope obtained through regeneration ([link]v. 3[/link]).

I.e., the salvation of the soul ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]9-10[/link]), which will be the consummation of God's full salvation. Grace was brought to us by the Lord's first coming ([link]John 1:17[/link]). It will be consummated by His second coming. On such grace we should set our hope.

verse.text: As children of [xref]a[/xref]obedience, do not be [note]1[/note]fashioned according to the former [xref]b[/xref]lusts in your [xref]c[/xref]ignorance;
verse.note: As in [link]Rom. 12:2[/link]. [i]Do not be fashioned[/i] denotes a state that is a path on which God's elect, as sojourners, walk.

verse.text: But according to the [note]1[/note]Holy One who [xref]a[/xref]called you, you yourselves also [note]2[/note]be [xref]b[/xref]holy in all [i]your[/i] [xref]c[/xref]manner of life;
verse.note: The Holy One is the Triune God — the choosing Father, the redeeming Son, and the sanctifying Spirit ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]). The Father regenerates His elect, imparting His holy nature into them ([link]v. 3[/link]); the Son redeemed them with His blood from the vain manner of life ([link]vv. 18-19[/link]); and the Spirit sanctifies them according to the Father's holy nature, separating them from anything other than God ([link]v. 2[/link]) that they, by the holy nature of the Father, may be holy in all their manner of life, even as holy as God Himself ([link]vv. 15-16[/link]).
Through the sanctification of the Spirit ([link]v. 2[/link]), based on regeneration ([link]v. 3[/link]), which brings us the holy nature of God and issues in a holy life.

verse.text: Because it is written, "You shall be [xref]a[/xref]holy because I am holy."

And if you call [i]as[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Father the One who [xref]b[/xref]without respect of persons [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]judges according to each one's [note]3[/note]work, pass the time of your [xref]d[/xref]sojourning in [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]fear,
verse.note: The Holy One, who as the Father has called us, has regenerated us to produce a holy family — a holy Father with holy children. As holy children, we should walk in a holy manner of life. Otherwise, the Father will become the Judge ([link]4:17[/link]) and will deal with our unholiness. He begot us with life inwardly that we might have His holy nature; He disciplines us with judgment outwardly that we may partake of His holiness ([link]Heb. 12:9-10[/link]). His judgment is according to our work, our conduct, without respect of persons. Hence, we should pass the time of our sojourning in fear. If we call Him our Father, we also should fear Him as our Judge and live a holy life in fear.

Peter "is not speaking of the final judgment of the soul. In that sense 'the Father judgeth no man, but has committed all judgment to the Son' [[link]John 5:22[/link]]. The thing spoken of here is the daily judgment of God's government in this world, exercised with regard to His children. Accordingly it says, 'the time of your sojourn[ing]' here" (Darby). This is God's judgment on His own household ([link]4:17[/link]).[br][br]Since these two Epistles are concerned with the government of God, the judgment of God and of the Lord is referred to repeatedly ([link]2:23[/link]; [link]4:5-6[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 2:3-4[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]3:7[/link]) as one of the main items. God's judgment began from the angels ([link]2 Pet. 2:3-4[/link]) and passed through the generations of man in the Old Testament ([link]2 Pet. 2:5-9[/link]). In the New Testament age it begins from the house of God ([link]v. 17[/link]; [link]2:23[/link]; [link]4:6[/link], [link]17[/link]) and continues until the coming of the day of the Lord ([link]2 Pet. 3:10[/link]), which will be a day of judgment on the Jews, the believers, and the Gentiles before the millennium (see note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in 2 Pet. 3[/link]). After the millennium all the dead, including men and demons, will be judged and will perish ([link]4:5[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 3:7[/link]), and the heavens and the earth will be consumed by fire ([link]2 Pet. 3:10b[/link], [link]12[/link]). The results of the various judgments are not the same. Some judgments result in a disciplinary dealing, some in a dispensational punishment, and some in eternal perdition (see note [link]1[sup]5[/sup], point 2, in 2 Pet. 2[/link]). However, by all these judgments the Lord God will clear up and purify the entire universe that He may have a new heaven and a new earth for a new universe filled with His righteousness ([link]2 Pet. 3:13[/link]) for His delight.
I.e., conduct, behavior; as in [link]Rom. 3:20[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:16[/link].

A holy fear, as in [link]Phil. 2:12[/link]; i.e., a healthy, serious caution that leads us to behave holily. Such fear is mentioned a number of times in this book (see reference 17e) because this book's teaching concerns the government of God.

verse.text: Knowing that [i]it was[/i] not with corruptible things, with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]silver or gold, [i]that[/i] you were [xref]b[/xref]redeemed [xref]c[/xref]from your [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]vain manner of life handed down from your fathers,
verse.note: Lit., something silver or something gold (e.g., a coin).

The vain manner of life is in contrast to the holy manner of life in [link]v. 15[/link]. As a general principle, the blood of Christ has redeemed us from sins, transgressions, lawlessness, and all sinful things ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:15[/link]; [link]Titus 2:14[/link]). Here is an exception: Christ's blood has redeemed us from our old, vain manner of life, because the emphasis here is not on sinfulness but on the manner of life. The whole chapter emphasizes the holy manner of life that God's chosen people should have in their sojourn. Not only is the Spirit's sanctification for this, even Christ's redemption is for this — to separate us from our vain manner of life handed down from our fathers. Knowing that this was accomplished with the highest price, the precious blood of Christ, we should pass the days of our sojourning in fear ([link]v. 17[/link]).[br][br]Our old manner of life, a life in lusts ([link]v. 14[/link]), had no meaning and no goal; hence, it was vain. But now our goal is to live a holy life that we may express God in His holiness ([link]vv. 15-16[/link]).

verse.text: But with [note]1[/note]precious [xref]a[/xref]blood, as of a [xref]b[/xref]Lamb [xref]c[/xref]without blemish and without spot, [i]the blood[/i] of Christ;
verse.note: The blood of Christ, by which we are sprinkled and thus marked out from the common people, is more precious than silver and gold. The highest price was paid for our redemption that we might be redeemed from a vain manner of life to a holy life ([link]vv. 18[/link], [link]15[/link]). For this we should have a holy fear, a healthy, serious caution before God, so that, as God's elect, redeemed with such a high price, we will not miss the purpose of this most high redemption of Christ.

verse.text: Who was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]foreknown [xref]b[/xref]before the foundation of the world but has been [xref]c[/xref]manifested in the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]last of times for your sake,
verse.note: Christ was foreordained, prepared, by God to be the redeeming Lamb ([link]John 1:29[/link]) for His elect according to His foreknowledge before the foundation of the world. This was done according to God's eternal purpose and plan; it did not happen accidentally. Hence, in the eternal view of God, from the foundation of the world, that is, from the fall of man as part of the world, Christ was slain ([link]Rev. 13:8[/link]).
Referring to the end of the Old Testament times. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 1[/link].

verse.text: Who [note]1[/note]through Him believe into God, who [xref]a[/xref]raised Him from the dead and [note]2[/note]gave Him [xref]b[/xref]glory, so that your [note]3[/note]faith and [xref]c[/xref]hope are in God.
verse.note: Our believing into Christ brought us into an organic union with Him ([link]Gal. 3:26-27[/link]). Then through Him we believe into God to be one with Him and participate in all His riches.
This is to glorify Him with glory ([link]v. 11[/link]) and is the Father's answer to His prayer ([link]John 17:1[/link]).
See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 13[/link].

verse.text: Since you have [note]1[/note]purified your [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]souls by your obedience to the [note]3[/note]truth unto unfeigned [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]brotherly love, love one another [note]5[/note]from a pure heart fervently,
verse.note: The purifying of our souls is the Spirit's sanctifying of our disposition that we may live a holy life in God's holy nature ([link]vv. 15-16[/link]). It is deeper than the purifying of our sins ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]) and the cleansing of sin ([link]1 John 1:7[/link]). The latter two are the purifying of our outward doing; the former is the purifying of our inward being — the soul. This purifying is like the washing of the water in the word in [link]Eph. 5:26[/link] (see note 3 there).

Our soul is composed of our mind, emotion, and will, which are also parts of our heart. To have our soul purified is to have our mind, emotion, and will, as parts of our heart, purified from any kind of defilement or contamination ([link]Acts 15:9[/link]; [link]James 4:8[/link]). Actually, this means to have our mind, emotion, and will delivered from all things other than God and fixed on God as the sole object and unique goal. This kind of purification is accomplished by our obedience to the truth, which is the content and reality of our faith (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], point 2, in 1 Tim. 1[/link]). When we obey the truth, the content and reality of our faith in Christ, our entire soul is concentrated on God and is thus purified from all things other than God. This is to have our souls saved from all filthiness by our receiving the implanted word ([link]James 1:21[/link]), which is the sanctifying truth ([link]John 17:17[/link]).
The sanctifying truth, which is God's word of reality, i.e., of truth ([link]John 17:17[/link] and notes).

Since the purifying of our souls causes our entire being to be concentrated on God that we may love Him with all our heart, with all our soul, and with all our mind ([link]Mark 12:30[/link]), such purifying issues in unfeigned brotherly love, our loving from the heart fervently those whom God loves. First, God's regeneration issues in a holy living ([link]vv. 15-16[/link]); then God's sanctification (purification) issues in brotherly love.
Some MSS read, from the heart fervently.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Having been [xref]a[/xref]regenerated not of corruptible [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]seed but of incorruptible, through [i]the[/i] [xref]c[/xref]living and abiding word of God.
verse.note: This verse modifies [link]v. 22[/link]. Having been regenerated, we have purified our souls unto brotherly love. Regeneration with the divine life is the base, the ground, for the purifying, sanctifying, of our souls unto unfeigned brotherly love. This section of the Word begins and ends with regeneration, which issues in a holy living toward God and brotherly love toward the saints.

A seed is a container of life. The word of God, as the incorruptible seed, contains God's life. Hence, it is living and abiding. Through this word we were regenerated. It is God's living and abiding word of life that conveys God's life into our spirit for our regeneration.

verse.text: For "all [note]1[/note]flesh is like [xref]a[/xref]grass, and all its glory like the flower of grass. The grass has withered, and the flower has fallen off,
verse.note: Referring to fallen man. The entire fallen human race is like withering grass, and its glory like the falling flower of grass. The believers were once like that, but the living and abiding word of the Lord, as the seed sown into them through regeneration, has changed their nature, making them living and abiding forever.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]word of the [note]2[/note]Lord abides forever." And this is the [xref]a[/xref]word which has been announced to you as the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]gospel.
verse.note: [i]Word[/i] in [link]v. 23[/link] refers to the constant word; [i]word[/i] here (used twice) refers to the instant word. When the constant word is spoken to us, it becomes the instant word.
Referring to God in [link]v. 23[/link], indicating that the Lord Jesus is God.
The word announced by the apostles is the gospel that regenerates the believers.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore putting away all [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]malice and all guile and [xref]b[/xref]hypocrisies and envyings and all evil speakings,
verse.note: The exhortation in [link]vv. 1-10[/link] is based on what is unveiled in [link]ch. 1[/link]. Three main things accomplished in the believers by the Triune God are stressed in ch. 1: the Father's regeneration ([link]1:3[/link], [link]23[/link]), the Son's redemption ([link]1:2[/link], [link]18-19[/link]), and the Spirit's sanctification ([link]1:2[/link]). These make the believers a holy people, who live a holy life ([link]1:15-16[/link]). Based on this, Peter charged the believers to grow in life ([link]v. 2[/link]) for the building up of a spiritual house ([link]v. 5[/link]).

The five negative things mentioned here constitute a sequence. Malice is the root, the source, and evil speaking is the expression. Guile, hypocrisies, and envies are the downward steps of the development from the source toward the expression.

verse.text: As [note]1[/note]newborn [xref]a[/xref]babes, long for the [note]2[/note]guileless [xref]b[/xref]milk [note]3[/note]of the word in order that by it you may [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]grow [note]5[/note]unto [xref]d[/xref]salvation,
verse.note: Born through regeneration ([link]1:3[/link], [link]23[/link]), the believers become babes who can grow in life unto further salvation, and that for God's building, by being nourished with the spiritual milk.
In contrast to [i]guile[/i] in [link]v. 1[/link]. I.e., without false purpose, without any goal other than to nourish the soul.

The Greek word, translated [i]reasonable[/i] in [link]Rom. 12:1[/link], is an adjective, derived from the noun [i]word;[/i] hence, [i]of the word;[/i] having the sense of pertaining to the mind (in contrast to the body), to the rational faculties; hence, rational, logical, reasonable. The milk of the word is not milk for the body but milk for the soul, the inner being. It is conveyed in the word of God to nourish our inner man through the understanding of our rational mind and is assimilated by our mental faculties.

To grow is a matter of life and in life. We received the divine life through regeneration, and we need to grow in this life and with this life by being nourished with the milk conveyed in the word of God.

I.e., resulting in. Growth in life results in salvation. Salvation here, as the result of growth in life, is not initial salvation. God's full and complete salvation has a long span — from regeneration, including justification, to glorification ([link]Rom. 8:30[/link]). At regeneration we receive initial salvation (see note [link]5[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]). Then we need to grow by feeding on Christ as the nourishing milk in the word of God, unto full salvation, unto maturity for glorification. This will be the salvation of our soul, which will be revealed to us at the revelation of the Lord Jesus ([link]1:5[/link] and note 5; [link]1:9-10[/link], [link]13[/link]). However, according to the context, [i]unto salvation[/i] here refers directly to [i]being built up as a spiritual house into a holy priesthood to offer up spiritual sacrifices[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link], and to [i]tell out the virtues of Him[/i] in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: If you have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tasted that the Lord is [note]2[/note]good.
verse.note: The Lord can be tasted, and His taste is pleasant and good. If we have tasted Him, we will long for the nourishing milk in His word ([link]v. 2[/link]).
Or, pleasant, kind.

verse.text: Coming to Him, a [note]1[/note]living [xref]a[/xref]stone, [xref]b[/xref]rejected by men but with God [xref]c[/xref]chosen [i]and[/i] [note]2[/note]precious,
verse.note: A living stone is one that not only possesses life but also grows in life. This is Christ for God's building. Here Peter changed his metaphor from a seed, which is of the vegetable life ([link]1:23-24[/link]), to a stone, which is of the minerals. The seed is for life-planting; the stone is for building ([link]v. 5[/link]). Peter's thought went on from life-planting to God's building. As life to us, Christ is the seed; for God's building, He is the stone. After receiving Him as the seed of life, we need to grow that we may experience Him as the stone living in us. Thus He will make us also living stones, transformed with His stone nature, that we may be built together with others as a spiritual house upon Him as both the foundation and the cornerstone ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]).
Or, held in honor; differing from the word used in [link]1:19[/link]. There the word denotes preciousness in essence; here it indicates preciousness that is recognized and held in honor by men.

verse.text: You yourselves also, as [note]1[/note]living [xref]a[/xref]stones, are being [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]built up as a [note]3[/note]spiritual [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]house [note]5[/note]into a [note]6[/note]holy [note]7[/note]priesthood to offer up [note]8[/note]spiritual sacrifices [xref]d[/xref]acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.
verse.note: We, the believers in Christ, are living stones, like Christ, through regeneration and transformation. We were created of clay ([link]Rom. 9:21[/link]). But at regeneration we received the seed of the divine life, which by its growing in us transforms us into living stones. At Peter's conversion the Lord gave him a new name, Peter — a stone ([link]John 1:42[/link]); and when Peter received the revelation concerning Christ, the Lord revealed further that He was the rock — a stone ([link]Matt. 16:16-18[/link]). By these two incidents Peter received the impression that both Christ and His believers are stones for God's building.
Feeding on Christ by taking in the nourishing milk in the word of God is not only for growing in life but also for building up. Growing is for building up.

Although the nourishing milk of the word is for the soul through the mind, it eventually nourishes our spirit, making us not soulish but spiritual, suitable for being built up as a spiritual house of God.

God's goal in the believers is to have a house built up with living stones — not separated and scattered stones, nor even stones merely gathered and piled up together, but stones built up one with another.
Some ancient MSS omit, into.

[i]Spiritual[/i] denotes the capacity of the divine life to live and grow; [i]holy,[/i] the capacity of the divine nature to separate and sanctify. The house of God subsists mainly by the divine life; hence, it is spiritual. The priesthood subsists mainly by the divine nature; hence, it is holy.

The holy priesthood is the spiritual house. In the New Testament three Greek words are used in relation to the priests: [i]hierosune,[/i] referring to the priestly office, as in [link]Heb. 7:12[/link]; [i]hierateia,[/i] referring to the priestly service, as in [link]Heb. 7:5[/link]; and [i]hierateuma,[/i] referring to the assembly of priests, a body of priests, a priesthood, as in this verse and [link]v. 9[/link]. The coordinated body of priests is the built-up spiritual house. Although Peter did not address his two Epistles to the church or use the term [i]church[/i] in this verse in stressing the corporate life of the believers, he did use the terms [i]spiritual house[/i] and [i]holy priesthood[/i] to indicate the church life. It is not the spiritual life lived in an individualistic way, but the spiritual life lived in a corporate way, that can fulfill God's purpose and satisfy His desire. He wants a spiritual house for His dwelling, a priestly body, a priesthood, for His service. Peter's view concerning the believers' corporate service in coordination is the same as Paul's in [link]Rom. 12[/link]. This service issues from the three vital steps in the spiritual life: being born anew ([link]v. 2a[/link]), growing in life by being nourished with Christ ([link]v. 2b[/link]), and being built up with the believers.

The spiritual sacrifices that the believers offer in the New Testament age according to God's economy are: (1) Christ as the reality of all the sacrifices of the Old Testament types, such as the burnt offering, meal offering, peace offering, sin offering, and trespass offering ([link]Lev. 1-5[/link]); (2) the sinners saved by our gospel preaching, offered as members of Christ ([link]Rom. 15:16[/link]); and (3) our body, our praises, and the things that we do for God ([link]Rom. 12:1[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:15-16[/link]; [link]Phil. 4:18[/link]).

verse.text: For it is contained in Scripture: [xref]a[/xref]"Behold, I lay in Zion a [note]1[/note]cornerstone, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]chosen [i]and[/i] [note]3[/note]precious; and he who [xref]c[/xref]believes on Him shall by no means be put to shame."
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 2[/link].
Christ is a stone chosen by God to be the cornerstone for His building ([link]Eph. 2:20[/link]).
See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: To you therefore who believe is the [note]1[/note]preciousness; but to the unbelieving, [xref]a[/xref]"The stone which the [note]2[/note]builders [xref]b[/xref]rejected, this has [note]3[/note]become the head of the corner,"
verse.note: In Greek, a word kindred to [i]precious[/i] in [link]vv. 4[/link], [link]6[/link]. The very Christ chosen by God as a stone, even a cornerstone that is precious to God, is the preciousness to His believers; but to the unbelievers He is a rejected, despised stone.

The Jewish leaders in Judaism ([link]Acts 4:11[/link]), who should have been building the house of God. They rejected Christ to the uttermost. The Lord predicted that they would do this ([link]Matt. 21:38-42[/link]).
In resurrection Christ became the head of the corner. In his early preaching Peter had already declared this to the Jews ([link]Acts 4:10-11[/link]).

verse.text: And, [xref]a[/xref]"A stone of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]stumbling and a rock of [xref]c[/xref]offense"; who [xref]d[/xref]stumble at [note]2[/note]the word, being disobedient, to [note]3[/note]which also they were [xref]e[/xref]appointed.
verse.note: The reliable Christ ([link]v. 6[/link]), being rejected, became a stumbling stone, on which the rejecting Judaizers stumbled ([link]Matt. 21:44a[/link]).
I.e., the word quoted in [link]vv. 6-8[/link].
Referring to the Jews' disobedience, which resulted in their stumbling.

verse.text: But you are a [xref]a[/xref]chosen [note]1[/note]race, a [note]2[/note]royal [xref]b[/xref]priesthood, a [note]3[/note]holy nation, a people acquired for a possession, so that you may [note]4[/note]tell out the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]virtues of Him who has [xref]d[/xref]called you out of [note]6[/note][xref]e[/xref]darkness into His marvelous [note]6[/note][xref]f[/xref]light;
verse.note: [i]Race, priesthood, nation,[/i] and [i]people[/i] are all collective nouns, referring to the believers corporately. As a race, we, the believers, are chosen; as a priesthood, a body of priests, we are royal, kingly; as a nation, we are holy; as a people, we are God's possession, a possession particularly acquired and owned by God as His treasure ([link]Titus 2:14[/link] and note 3). [i]Chosen race[/i] denotes our descent from God; [i]royal priesthood,[/i] our service to God; [i]holy nation,[/i] our being a community for God; and [i]people acquired for a possession,[/i] our preciousness to God. These are all in a corporate sense. Hence, we need to be built together ([link]v. 5[/link]).

See notes [link]5[sup]6[/sup][/link] and [link]5[sup]7[/sup][/link]. [i]Royal[/i] denotes the status of our priesthood, which is kingly, like that of Christ the King, our High Priest, typified by Melchizedek ([link]Heb. 7:1-2[/link], [link]26[/link], and note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link]; [link]Gen. 14:18[/link]).
See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link]. [i]Holy[/i] denotes the nature of the nation.

Or, proclaim abroad. First, we must be born anew and grow in life ([link]v. 2[/link]), and then we must be built up and serve corporately ([link]v. 5[/link]). Now we need to proclaim abroad, to tell out. To serve corporately is to satisfy God by offering up Christ as spiritual sacrifices; to tell out is to benefit others by proclaiming abroad as the gospel the virtues of the One who has called us out of darkness into His marvelous light.

Or, excellencies, excellent and glorious virtues ([link]2 Pet. 1:3[/link] and note 11); referring to what God is and has, and to the marvelous light of God, which consummates in His glory. To and by His virtue and glory God has called us ([link]2 Pet. 1:3[/link]).

Darkness is the expression and sphere of Satan in death; light is the expression and sphere of God in life. God has called us, delivered us, out of Satan's death-realm of darkness into His life-realm of light ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Who once were [xref]a[/xref]not a people but now are the people of God; who had not [i]previously[/i] been shown mercy but have now been shown mercy.
verse.note: This word from [link]Hosea 2:23[/link] was quoted by Paul in [link]Rom. 9:24-27[/link], in reference first to the Gentiles and then to the remnant of Israel, "for not all who are out of Israel are Israel" ([link]Rom. 9:6[/link]). Here Peter, quoting this word, referred to the recipients of his letter, the scattered Jewish believers. At one time they were out of Israel but were not Israel. Hence, they were not God's people in the New Testament sense. Now, after being called by God, they became God's people, God's particular possession, as a treasure to God. They were shown God's mercy, which they had never been shown before.

verse.text: Beloved, I entreat [i]you[/i] as [xref]a[/xref]strangers and [xref]b[/xref]sojourners to [xref]c[/xref]abstain from [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]fleshly lusts, which [xref]e[/xref]war against the [note]1[/note][xref]f[/xref]soul,
verse.note: The fleshly lusts are in man's fallen body ([link]Rom. 7:18[/link], [link]23-24[/link]) and are warring against man's soul — man's inner being, composed of his mind, will, and emotion ([link]Rom. 7:19-23[/link]).

verse.text: Having your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]manner of life [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]excellent among the Gentiles, so that in the matter concerning which they [xref]c[/xref]speak against you as evildoers they may, by your [xref]d[/xref]good works, as they see [i]them[/i] with their own eyes, [xref]e[/xref]glorify God in the day of [i]His[/i] [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]visitation.
verse.note: This must be the holy manner of life ([link]1:15[/link]) and the good manner of life in Christ ([link]3:16[/link]), a life not only for God but filled and saturated with God. This manner of life is versus the vain manner of life of the unbelievers ([link]1:18[/link]).
I.e., beautiful in its virtues.

The basic meaning of the Greek word is [i]observation, inspection, oversight, a looking upon.[/i] The day of visitation is the day on which God will look upon His sojourning people, as a shepherd watches over his wandering sheep, and will become the Shepherd and Overseer of their souls ([link]v. 25[/link]). Hence, the day of God's visitation is the time of God's overseeing care.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Be [xref]a[/xref]subject to every human [note]2[/note]institution [note]3[/note]for the Lord's sake, whether to a [xref]b[/xref]king as being supreme,
verse.note: All the items from this verse through [link]v. 20[/link] are details showing the good works of the excellent manner of life ([link]v. 12[/link]).
Lit., creation; as in [link]Col. 1:15[/link]. Referring to anything made, such as a creature, a building, a regulation, or an ordinance.
For the expression and glorification of the Lord ([link]v. 12[/link]).

verse.text: Or to governors as being sent by him for [xref]a[/xref]vengeance on evildoers and praise of those who do [xref]b[/xref]good.
For so is the [xref]a[/xref]will of God, that by doing good you would muzzle the [xref]b[/xref]ignorance of [note]1[/note]foolish men;
verse.note: The slanderers ([link]v. 12[/link]).

verse.text: As [xref]a[/xref]free, and yet [xref]b[/xref]not having freedom as a covering for evil, but as [xref]c[/xref]slaves of God.
[xref]a[/xref]Honor all men. [xref]b[/xref]Love the [note]1[/note]brotherhood. [xref]c[/xref]Fear God. Honor the [xref]d[/xref]king.
verse.note: The aggregate of the brothers, the family of the brothers, the brothers in the feeling of brotherliness (also in [link]5:9[/link]).

verse.text: Household [xref]a[/xref]servants, be subject in all [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]fear to your masters, not only to the good and forbearing but also to the crooked.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: For this is [note]1[/note]grace, if anyone, [note]2[/note]because of a [xref]a[/xref]consciousness of God, bears sorrows by suffering [note]3[/note]unjustly.
verse.note: Grace here refers to the motivation of the divine life within us and its expression in our living, which becomes in our behavior gracious and acceptable in the eyes of both man and God ([link]v. 20[/link]). The same Greek word is used in [link]Luke 6:33-34[/link] and [link]Rom. 7:25[/link] for [i]thanks.[/i] So in the next verse.

Or, for conscience toward God. The consciousness of God is the consciousness of one's relation to God, indicating that one is living in an intimate fellowship with God, having and keeping a good and pure conscience toward God ([link]3:16[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:5[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]3:9[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:3[/link]).

According to the context ([link]vv. 20-21[/link]), this must be the mistreatment inflicted by the unbelieving masters, who opposed and persecuted their believing servants because of their Christian testimony ([link]3:14-18[/link]; [link]4:12-16[/link]).

verse.text: For what [note]1[/note]glory is it if, while sinning and being buffeted, you endure? But if, while doing good and [xref]a[/xref]suffering, you endure, this is grace with God.
verse.note: Or, boast.

verse.text: For to [note]1[/note]this you were [xref]a[/xref]called, because Christ also [xref]b[/xref]suffered on your behalf, leaving you a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]model so that you may follow in His steps;
verse.note: We have been called to enjoy grace and express God in the midst of our suffering unjustly ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]).

Lit., a writing copy, an underwriting (used by students to trace letters and thereby learn to draw them). The Lord has set His suffering life before us so that we can copy it by tracing and following His steps. This does not refer to a mere imitation of Him and His life but to a reproduction of Him that comes from enjoying Him as grace in our sufferings (see note [link]19[sup]1[/sup][/link]), so that He Himself as the indwelling Spirit, with all the riches of His life, reproduces Himself in us. We become the reproduction of the original writing copy, not a mere imitation of Him produced by taking Him as our outward model.

verse.text: Who committed no [xref]a[/xref]sin, nor was guile found in His [xref]b[/xref]mouth;
Who being reviled did [xref]a[/xref]not revile in return; suffering, He did not threaten but kept committing [note]1[/note][i]all[/i] to Him who [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]judges righteously;
verse.note: [i]All,[/i] inserted here, refers to all the sufferings of the Lord. The Lord kept committing all His insults and injuries to Him who judges righteously in His government, the righteous God, to whom He submitted Himself. This indicates that the Lord recognized God's government while He was living a human life on earth.
See note [link]17[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Who Himself [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bore up our sins in His [xref]b[/xref]body on the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]tree, in order that we, [note]3[/note]having [xref]d[/xref]died to sins, might [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]live [note]5[/note]to righteousness; by whose [note]6[/note][xref]f[/xref]bruise you were [note]7[/note]healed.
verse.note: This points out that when the Lord offered up Himself as a sacrifice ([link]Heb. 7:27[/link]) on the cross, He bore up our sins in His body on the cross, the true altar for propitiation.
The cross made of wood, a Roman instrument of capital punishment used for the execution of malefactors, as prophesied in the Old Testament ([link]Deut. 21:23[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:13[/link]).
Lit., being away from; hence, having died to. In the death of Christ we have died to sins ([link]Rom. 6:8[/link], [link]10-11[/link], [link]18[/link]).
In the resurrection of Christ ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]; [link]John 14:19[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:11[/link]).
Righteousness is a matter of God's government. We were saved so that we might live rightly under the government of God, that is, in a way that matches the righteous requirements of His government.
A suffering that resulted in death.
The healing of death. We were dead ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link]), but Christ's suffering of death healed our death that we might live in His resurrection.

verse.text: For you were like [xref]a[/xref]sheep being led astray, but you have now [note]1[/note]returned to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Shepherd and [xref]c[/xref]Overseer of your [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]souls.
verse.note: Or, turned back.

Christ was our Redeemer in His death on the tree ([link]v. 24[/link]). Now He is our soul's Shepherd and Overseer in the resurrection life within us. As such, He is able to guide us and supply us with life that we may follow in His steps according to the model of His suffering ([link]v. 21[/link]).

Our soul is our inner being, our real person. Our Lord, as the Shepherd and Overseer of our souls, shepherds us by caring for the welfare of our inner being and by exercising His oversight over the condition of our real person.

verse.text: In [note]1[/note]like manner, [xref]a[/xref]wives, be subject to your own husbands, that even if any disobey the [note]2[/note]word, they will be gained without the [note]2[/note]word through the manner of life of their [xref]b[/xref]wives,
verse.note: Referring to [link]2:18[/link].
The word of God ([link]1 Pet. 1:23[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]Rom. 10:8[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:13[/link]).

verse.text: Seeing with their own eyes your [note]1[/note]pure manner of life [note]2[/note]in [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]fear.
verse.note: Or, chaste; in Greek, a derivative from the same root as [i]holy[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link] and [link]1:15[/link]. The pure and chaste manner of life must be the holy manner of life ([link]1:15[/link]), the excellent manner of life ([link]2:12[/link]), and the good manner of life ([link]v. 16[/link]).
[i]In fear[/i] modifies [i]pure manner of life.[/i]
See note [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Let your [xref]a[/xref]adorning not be the outward [note]1[/note]plaiting of hair and putting on of [xref]b[/xref]gold or clothing with garments,
verse.note: Women's hair is intended by God for their glory and as a sign of their submission ([link]1 Cor. 11:15[/link]; [link]S.S. 4:1[/link]; [link]6:5[/link]; [link]7:5[/link]). But it was misused by many, especially by those who lived in the luxurious and corrupt life of the Roman Empire at the time of this Epistle, to beautify their lustful flesh by adorning it extravagantly with gold and other costly things. Christian wives, as holy women, should absolutely abstain from this God-condemned practice.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]hidden man of the [xref]a[/xref]heart in the incorruptible [i]adornment[/i] of a meek and quiet [xref]b[/xref]spirit, which is very [xref]c[/xref]costly in the sight of God.
verse.note: That the hidden man of the heart has the incorruptible adornment of a meek and quiet spirit indicates that the meek and quiet spirit in us is the hidden man of our heart. Our heart is composed of all the parts of our soul — mind, emotion, and will — along with the main part of our spirit — the conscience ([link]Heb. 4:12[/link]). Among all these, our spirit is at the center; hence, our spirit is the hidden man of our heart. As wives, the sisters in the Lord should have as their adornment before God their inner being — the hidden man of their heart, which is adorned with a meek and quiet spirit. This spiritual adornment is very costly in the sight of God, and it is incorruptible, not like the material adornment of the plaiting of hair or the putting on of gold and garments, which is corruptible.

verse.text: For in this manner formerly the holy women also, who [xref]a[/xref]hoped in God, adorned themselves, being [xref]b[/xref]subject to their own husbands,
As Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him [xref]a[/xref]lord; whose children you have become, if you do good and do not [xref]b[/xref]fear any [note]1[/note]terror.
verse.note: Lit., fright, or, nervous excitement.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Husbands, in like manner dwell together with [i]them[/i] [note]1[/note]according to knowledge, as with the [note]2[/note]weaker, female [note]3[/note]vessel, [note]4[/note]assigning [xref]b[/xref]honor to [i]them[/i] as also to [xref]c[/xref]fellow heirs of the [note]5[/note]grace of life, that your prayers may not be hindered.
verse.note: I.e., in an intelligent and reasonable way, governed by human and spiritual knowledge that recognizes the nature of the marriage relationship and the weakness of the female, and not governed by any passion or emotion.
The female, according to nature in God's creation, is weaker than the male, physically and psychologically.

Man, including woman, was made a vessel to contain God ([link]Rom. 9:21[/link], [link]23[/link]), and the believers in Christ are vessels to contain Christ as the treasure ([link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]). Although the wives, as female vessels, are weaker, they are still vessels of the Lord and can be vessels unto honor ([link]2 Tim. 2:21[/link]).

The Greek word for [i]assigning[/i] means [i]to apportion, to portion out;[/i] hence, to assign to. The word for [i]honor[/i] means [i]preciousness, valuable worth.[/i] The husbands should appreciate the preciousness, the valuable worth, of the wives and apportion it, assign it, as honor to them, duly and reasonably, as also to fellow heirs of the grace of life.

The grace of life is God as life and life supply to us in His Trinity — the Father as the source of life, the Son as the course of life, and the Spirit as the flow of life, who flows within us, with the Son and the Father, as grace to us ([link]1 John 5:11-12[/link]; [link]John 7:38-39[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:1[/link]). All believers are heirs of this grace. See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And finally be all of the [xref]a[/xref]same mind, sympathetic, [xref]b[/xref]loving the brothers, [xref]c[/xref]tenderhearted, [xref]d[/xref]humble-minded;

Not rendering [xref]a[/xref]evil for evil or [xref]b[/xref]reviling for reviling, but on the contrary [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]blessing [i]one another,[/i] because you were [xref]d[/xref]called [note]2[/note]to this, that you might inherit [xref]e[/xref]blessing.
verse.note: The tense of the Greek participle means [i]be always blessing.[/i]

We have been called to bless others, so we, as a blessed people, should always bless others that we may inherit blessing. What we bless others with, we will inherit ourselves ([link]Matt. 10:13[/link]).

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]"he who desires to love life and see [note]1[/note]good days, let him cause his [xref]b[/xref]tongue to cease from evil and [i]his[/i] lips to speak no guile.
verse.note: Good days are days of good, referring to good things as blessings.

verse.text: And let him [xref]a[/xref]turn away from evil and do good; let him [xref]b[/xref]seek peace and pursue it;
For the [xref]a[/xref]eyes of the Lord are on the righteous, and His [xref]b[/xref]ears [i]incline[/i] to their petition; but the [xref]c[/xref]face of the Lord is against those who do evil."
And who will harm you if you become zealous for what is [xref]a[/xref]good?

But even if you [xref]a[/xref]suffer because of [xref]b[/xref]righteousness, you are [xref]c[/xref]blessed. And do not be [xref]d[/xref]afraid [i]with[/i] fear from them, nor be [xref]e[/xref]troubled,

But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctify Christ as [xref]b[/xref]Lord in your hearts, being always ready for a defense to everyone who asks of you an account concerning the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]hope which is in you,
verse.note: If we are terrified and troubled by the persecutors ([link]vv. 13-14[/link]), it will appear that we do not have the Lord in our hearts. So, in suffering persecution we should show others that we have Christ as Lord within us. This is to sanctify Him, to separate Him, from the other gods, not degrading Him so that He appears to be like the lifeless idols.
The living hope of the inheritance of eternal life. See notes [link chapter="1"]3[sup]6[/sup][/link] and [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Yet with [xref]a[/xref]meekness and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]fear, having a good [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]conscience, so that in the matter in which you are [xref]d[/xref]spoken against, those who [xref]e[/xref]revile your good [xref]f[/xref]manner of life [note]3[/note][xref]g[/xref]in Christ may be put to [xref]h[/xref]shame.
verse.note: A pious fear. See note [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
Since the conscience is a part of our human spirit ([link]Rom. 9:1[/link]; [link]8:16[/link]), to care for our conscience is to care for our spirit before God.
The Christian's good manner of life should be one that is in Christ. It is a living, a daily life, in the Spirit. This is higher than a living that is merely ethical and moral.

verse.text: For it is better, if the [xref]a[/xref]will of God should will [i]it,[/i] to [xref]b[/xref]suffer for doing good than for doing evil.

For Christ also has suffered once for [note]1[/note]sins, the Righteous [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]on behalf of the unrighteous, that He might bring you [xref]b[/xref]to God, on the one hand being put to death in the flesh, but on the other, made alive in the [note]3[/note]Spirit;
verse.note: [i]Sins[/i] here and in [link]2:24[/link], [link]1 Cor. 15:3[/link], and [link]Heb. 9:28[/link] refers to the sins we commit in our outward conduct; whereas [i]sin[/i] in [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link] and [link]Heb. 9:26[/link] refers to sin that is in our nature by birth. Christ died for our sins, bearing up our sins on the cross, that our sins might be forgiven by God. But He was made sin and took away the sin of the world that the problem of our sin might be solved. Peter did not deal first with sin in our nature but with sins in our conduct, in our manner of life ([link]v. 16[/link]). The emphasis of this book is that Christ's death redeemed us from our inherited vain manner of life ([link]1:18-19[/link]).

This indicates that Christ's death was for redemption, not for martyrdom. On the cross He was our Substitute and bore our sins; He, the righteous One, was judged on behalf of us, the unrighteous, by the righteous God according to His righteousness, that He might remove the barrier of our sins and bring us to God. This was to redeem us from our sins back to God, from our unrighteous manner of life back to the righteous God.

Not the Holy Spirit but the Spirit as the essence of Christ's divinity ([link]Rom. 1:4[/link]; cf. [link]John 4:24a[/link]). The crucifixion put Christ to death only in His flesh — which He received through His incarnation ([link]John 1:14[/link]) — not in His Spirit as His divinity. His Spirit as His divinity did not die at the cross when His flesh died; rather, His Spirit as His divinity was made alive, enlivened, with new power of life, so that in this empowered Spirit as His divinity He made a proclamation to the fallen angels after His death in the flesh and before His resurrection.

verse.text: In [note]1[/note]which also He went and [note]2[/note]proclaimed to the [note]3[/note]spirits in [note]4[/note]prison,
verse.note: This refers to the Spirit in [link]v. 18[/link], indicating and proving that Christ, after dying in His flesh, was still active in this Spirit.

Not to preach the good news but to proclaim the victory achieved by God, that is, that through Christ's death on the cross God destroyed Satan and his power of darkness ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]; [link]Col. 2:15[/link]).

Throughout the centuries great teachers of different schools have had varying interpretations concerning [i]the spirits in prison.[/i] The most acceptable according to the Scriptures is as follows: the spirits here refer not to the disembodied spirits of dead human beings held in Hades but to the angels (angels are spirits — [link]Heb. 1:14[/link]) who fell through disobedience at Noah's time ([link]v. 20[/link] and [i]Life-study of Genesis,[/i] Message Twenty-seven, pp. 363-4) and are imprisoned in pits of gloom, awaiting the judgment of the great day (2 Pet. [link]2:4-5[/link]; [link]Jude 6[/link]). After His death in the flesh, Christ in His living Spirit as His divinity went (probably to the abyss — [link]Rom. 10:7[/link]) to these rebellious angels to proclaim, perhaps, God's victory, accomplished through His incarnation in Christ and Christ's death in the flesh, over Satan's scheme to derange the divine plan.
Referring to Tartarus, the deep and gloomy pits ([link]2 Pet. 2:4[/link] and [link]Jude 6[/link]), where the fallen angels are kept.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Who had formerly disobeyed when the long-suffering of God waited in the days of [xref]a[/xref]Noah, while the ark was being prepared; [i]entering[/i] into which, a few, that is, eight souls, were [note]2[/note]brought safely through [note]3[/note]by [xref]b[/xref]water.
verse.note: Not human but angelic beings, different from the eight souls.
"The Greek means 'arrive safe into a place of security through difficulty or danger,' as [link]Acts 27:44[/link]" (Darby).

Water was the medium through which the saving was accomplished. The ark saved Noah and his family from God's judgment, the destruction of the world by the flood. But the water saved them from the corrupted generation and separated them unto a new age, just as the water of the Red Sea did for the children of Israel ([link]Exo. 14:22[/link], [link]29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:1-2[/link]) and the water of baptism for the New Testament believers ([link]v. 21[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Which [i]water,[/i] as the antitype, also now saves you, [i]that is,[/i] [note]2[/note]baptism, [note]3[/note]not a putting away of the filth of the flesh but the [note]4[/note]appeal of a good [xref]a[/xref]conscience unto God, through the [xref]b[/xref]resurrection of Jesus Christ,
verse.note: Referring to the water mentioned in the preceding verse, of which the water of baptism is the antitype. This indicates that Noah and his family's passing through the flood within the ark was a type of our passing through baptism. The water of the flood delivered them out of the old manner of life into a new environment; in like manner the water of baptism delivers us out of the inherited vain manner of life into a manner of life of resurrection in Christ. This is the main emphasis of this book. Christ redeemed us for this ([link]1:18-19[/link]). Christ's redemption was accomplished by Christ's death and was accepted and applied to us, in baptism, by the Spirit through Christ's resurrection. Now our daily walk should be in the Spirit of the resurrected Christ; it should be a walk in which we live Christ in resurrection through the life power of His Spirit ([link]Rom. 6:4-5[/link]). This is a new and excellent manner of life that glorifies God ([link]2:12[/link]).
In apposition to [i]antitype.[/i]

Baptism itself does not and cannot put away the filth of our flesh — the dirt of our fallen nature and the defilement of fleshly lust. The erroneous teaching concerning baptismal salvation, a teaching based on this verse and [link]Mark 16:16[/link] and [link]Acts 22:16[/link], is corrected here. Baptism is only a figure; its reality is Christ in resurrection as the life-giving Spirit, who applies to us all that Christ passed through in His crucifixion and resurrection, making these things real in our daily life.
