The Greek word denotes a question, an inquiry. Its meaning is very much disputed. The right meaning seems to be as indicated by Alford — "the seeking after God in a good and pure conscience." It is this that governs the proper Christian life. This kind of question, which asks for something, can be considered an appeal or demand. Peter's thought here may be that baptism is the baptized one's appeal to God for a good conscience toward God. Baptism, as a symbol, a counterpart of our belief in all the accomplishments of Christ, testifies that all the problems we have before God and with God have been solved. Hence, it is also a testimony, witnessing that in our conscience there is no more accusation and that instead we are full of peace and are confident that we have been baptized into the Triune God ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]) and have been organically united with Him through the resurrection of Christ, that is, by Christ in resurrection as the Spirit of life. Without the Spirit of Christ as its reality, baptism by water immediately becomes an empty and dead ritual.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Who is at the [xref]a[/xref]right hand of God, having gone into [xref]b[/xref]heaven, [xref]c[/xref]angels and [xref]d[/xref]authorities and powers being [xref]e[/xref]subjected to Him.
verse.note: This additional word not only unveils to us, further, the glorious result of the suffering of Christ — His exaltation after His resurrection and the high and honorable position He now holds in the heavens at the right hand of God — but also indicates how glorious and honorable is the organic union we have entered into with Him through baptism, for we were baptized into Him ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]).

verse.text: Since Christ therefore has [xref]a[/xref]suffered[note]1[/note] in the flesh, you also [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]arm yourselves with the [note]3[/note]same mind (because he who has [note]4[/note]suffered in the flesh has ceased from [xref]c[/xref]sin),
verse.note: Some MSS add, for us.
This indicates that the Christian life is a battle.

One main purpose of this book is to encourage and exhort the believers to follow the footsteps of Christ in their suffering of persecution ([link]1:6-7[/link]; [link]2:18-25[/link]; [link]3:8-17[/link]; [link]4:12-19[/link]). They should have the same mind that Christ had in His suffering ([link]3:18-22[/link]). The main function of our mind is to understand and realize. To live a life that follows the footsteps of Christ, we need a renewed mind ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]) to understand and realize the way Christ lived to fulfill God's purpose.

Pleasure heats up the lusts of our flesh ([link]v. 2[/link]); suffering cools them down. The purpose of Christ's redemption is to deliver us from our inherited vain manner of life ([link]1:18-19[/link]). Suffering responds to Christ's redemption in fulfilling this purpose, preserving us from a sinful manner of life, from the flood of dissoluteness ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]). Such suffering, mainly from persecution, is God's discipline in His governmental dealing. To undergo such suffering is to be judged, dealt with, and disciplined in the flesh by God ([link]v. 6[/link]). Hence, we should arm ourselves with a sober mind to endure such suffering.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]No longer to [xref]b[/xref]live the rest of the time in the flesh in the [xref]c[/xref]lusts of men, but in the [xref]d[/xref]will of God.
verse.note: I.e., no longer to live in the vain manner of life handed down from our fathers ([link]1:18[/link]), but in a holy and excellent manner of life ([link]1:15[/link]; [link]2:12[/link]), pure in holy fear and good in Christ ([link]3:2[/link], [link]16[/link]). This is the will of God.

verse.text: For the time which has passed is [xref]a[/xref]sufficient [i]for you[/i] to have carried out the [note]1[/note]desire of the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles, having gone on [note]2[/note]in licentiousness, lusts, debaucheries, carousings, drinking bouts, and lawless idolatries.
verse.note: Lit., purpose, will. I.e., intention, inclination; hence, desire.
I.e., in the vain manner of life ([link]1:18[/link]).

verse.text: In this they think it [note]1[/note]strange that you are not [note]2[/note]running together with [i]them[/i] into the same [note]3[/note]flood of [xref]a[/xref]dissoluteness, [note]4[/note]slandering [i]you;[/i]
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to be a host or a guest, to be foreign, alien; to entertain, to lodge; to think it strange.[/i] To live in the flesh in the lusts of men ([link]v. 2[/link]) is common among the unbelieving Gentiles, who are running together into the flood of dissoluteness. But to live a holy life in the will of God, not running together in the indulgence of lusts, is strange to them. It is a foreign thing, alien to them. They are surprised and astonished at it (cf. [link]v. 12[/link]).

Rushing on in a crowd like a band of revelers. This is to live in the flesh in the lusts of men ([link]v. 2[/link]), to carry out the desire of the Gentiles ([link]v. 3[/link]) in the vain manner of life ([link]1:18[/link]).

The Greek word means [i]a pouring forth, a pouring out upon[/i] (as in a tide); hence, a flood. It denotes here the overflowing indulgence of lusts, the excess of moral corruption and degradation, which is like a flood, into which one sinks when one runs into it.

I.e., speaking evilly of (you), speaking injuriously of (you) ([link]Acts 13:45[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:12[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]). The believers, whose behavior was thought strange, were slandered unjustly and accused of all manner of crimes.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Who will [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]render an account to [xref]b[/xref]Him who is ready to [note]3[/note]judge the living and the dead.
verse.note: Referring to the Gentiles ([link]v. 3[/link]), who are astonished at the believers' different manner of life and speak evilly of them ([link]v. 4[/link]).

I.e., to relate to God all that one has done and spoken in his entire life. This reveals the government of God over all men. He is ready to judge all, both the living and the dead. His judgment is His governmental administration by which He deals with the situation among men.

This must be to judge first the living among the nations (the Gentiles) at Christ's throne of glory before the millennium ([link]Matt. 25:31-46[/link]) and then the dead at the great white throne after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). This too will be God's governmental judgment, but it differs from the judgment on the believers in [link]v. 6[/link], which begins from the house of God in this age ([link]v. 17[/link]). See note [link]17[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: For unto this [i]end[/i] the gospel was announced also to [note]1[/note][i]those who are now[/i] dead, that they might be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]judged in the flesh according to men but live in the [note]3[/note]spirit according to God.
verse.note: [i]Those who are now dead[/i] refers to the dead believers in Christ, who suffered persecution because of their Christian testimony, as referred to in [link]1:6[/link]; [link]2:18-21[/link]; [link]3:16-17[/link]; and [link]4:12-19[/link]. This kind of persecution was considered by Peter in this book as God's judgment, which is according to the government of God and which begins from the house of God ([link]v. 17[/link]). The gospel was preached to these dead believers while they were living, that they might, on the one hand, be judged, dealt with, by God in the flesh according to men through the opposers' persecution, but, on the other hand, live in the spirit according to God by believing in Christ. This shows how strict and serious is the judgment of God in His governmental administration. If the believers, who have been obedient to the gospel, are dealt with by God's governmental judgment, how much more will those who oppose the gospel and slander the believers be judged by God's dealing ([link]vv. 17-18[/link])!
See note [link]17[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 1[/link].

The believers' spirit, regenerated and indwelt by the Spirit of God ([link]John 3:6[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:10-11[/link]). Thus it has become a mingled spirit, in which the believers live and walk ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]).

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]end of all things has drawn [xref]a[/xref]near. Therefore [note]2[/note]be sober-minded and [note]3[/note]be [xref]b[/xref]sober unto [xref]c[/xref]prayers.
verse.note: All things on which the flesh rests will pass away, and the end of them, the apostle tells us here, has drawn near. This warns us that a life lived in the flesh in the lusts of men ([link]v. 2[/link]) will soon be ended, for it is related to all things that will shortly pass away. Therefore, we should be sober-minded and be sober unto prayers.
The Greek word means [i]be of a sound mind, have a mind of sobriety, be able to understand things properly and thoroughly without being disturbed.[/i]

I.e., be sober to watch, be vigilant. This is to be on guard; hence, to be sober unto prayers. This equals the Lord's word, "Watch and pray" ([link]Matt. 26:41[/link]; [link]Luke 21:36[/link]). See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: Above all, have [xref]a[/xref]fervent love among yourselves, because [xref]b[/xref]love [xref]c[/xref]covers a multitude of sins.
Be [xref]a[/xref]hospitable to one another without [xref]b[/xref]murmuring,
[xref]a[/xref]Each one, as he has received a gift, [note]1[/note]ministering it among yourselves as good [xref]b[/xref]stewards of the [note]2[/note]varied [xref]c[/xref]grace of God.
verse.note: Or, serving.

See notes [link]2[sup]12[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]. The varied grace of God, like the "all grace" in [link]ch. 5[/link], is the rich supply of life, which is the Triune God ministered into us in many aspects ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]; [link]12:9[/link]). As good stewards, we should minister such grace, not merely doctrine nor any vain thing, to the church and the saints by the gift we have received.

verse.text: If anyone speaks, as [i]speaking[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]oracles of God; if anyone ministers, as [i]ministering[/i] out of the strength which God [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]supplies; that in all things God may be [xref]c[/xref]glorified [note]3[/note]through Jesus Christ, [xref]d[/xref]to whom is the [note]4[/note]glory and the might forever and ever. Amen.
verse.note: The divine speakings or utterances as revelations. In the ministry of grace, as mentioned in [link]v. 10[/link], our speaking should be God's speaking, God's utterance, which conveys divine revelation.
Through the Spirit of Christ, God supplies to us the serving strength of Christ's resurrection life ([link]Phil. 1:19[/link]; [link]4:13[/link]).
This indicates that all our ministry of grace, whether in speaking or in serving, should be full of Christ, that God may be glorified through Christ in all things.

Glory is without and might is within. Might supplies the strength within us; glory is God glorified upon us. Hence, [i]glory[/i] corresponds with [i]glorified,[/i] and [i]might[/i] with [i]strength.[/i]

verse.text: Beloved, do not think that the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fiery ordeal among you, coming to you for a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]trial, is [note]3[/note]strange, as if [i]it were[/i] a [note]3[/note]strange thing happening to you;
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]fiery ordeal[/i] means [i]burning,[/i] signifying the burning of a smelting furnace for the purifying of gold and silver ([link]Prov. 27:21[/link]; [link]Psa. 66:10[/link]); this is similar to the metaphor used in [link]1:7[/link]. Peter considered the persecution that the believers suffered as such a burning furnace used by God to purify their life. This is God's way to deal with the believers in the judgment of His governmental administration, which begins from His own house ([link]vv. 17-19[/link]).
Or, testing.
See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link]. Fiery persecution is common to the believers; they should not think that it is strange or alien to them, and they should not be surprised and astonished by it.

verse.text: But inasmuch as you share in the [xref]a[/xref]sufferings of Christ, [xref]b[/xref]rejoice, so that also at the [xref]c[/xref]revelation of His glory you may rejoice [xref]d[/xref]exultingly.

If you are [xref]a[/xref]reproached in the [note]1[/note]name of [xref]b[/xref]Christ, you are [xref]c[/xref]blessed, because [note]2[/note]the Spirit of glory and of God [note]3[/note]rests upon you.
verse.note: The name denotes the person. To be in the name of Christ is actually to be in the person of Christ, in Christ Himself. The believers, having believed into Christ ([link]John 3:15[/link]) and having been baptized into His name ([link]Acts 19:5[/link]), that is, into Himself ([link]Gal. 3:27[/link]), are in Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]) and are one with Him ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). When they are reproached in His name, they are reproached with Him, sharing in His sufferings ([link]v. 13[/link]), in the fellowship of His sufferings ([link]Phil. 3:10[/link]).

Lit., the Spirit of glory and that of God. The Spirit of glory is the Spirit of God. The Spirit of glory is the One through whom Christ was glorified in His resurrection ([link]Rom. 1:4[/link]). This very Spirit of glory, being the Spirit of God Himself, rests upon the suffering believers in their persecution, for the glorifying of the resurrected and exalted Christ, who is now in glory ([link]v. 13[/link]).
The same word as in [link]Matt. 11:28[/link]. The sense here is [i]to remain.[/i]

verse.text: For let none of you [xref]a[/xref]suffer as a murderer or a thief or an evildoer or as a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]meddler into others' affairs;
verse.note: Lit., an overseer of others' affairs; denoting one who makes trouble by interfering in others' business.

verse.text: But if as a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Christian, let him not be [xref]b[/xref]ashamed, but let him [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]glorify God in this name.
verse.note: Gk. [i]Christianos,[/i] a word formed from Latin. The ending [i]ianos,[/i] denoting an adherent of someone, was applied to slaves belonging to the great families in the Roman Empire. One who worshipped the emperor, the Caesar, or [i]Kaisar,[/i] was called [i]Kaisarianos,[/i] which means [i]an adherent of Kaisar, a person who belongs to Kaisar.[/i] When people believed in Christ and became His followers, some in the Empire came to consider Christ a rival of their [i]Kaisar.[/i] Then, at Antioch ([link]Acts 11:26[/link]) they began to call the followers of Christ [i]Christianoi[/i] (Christians), adherents of Christ, as a nickname, a term of reproach. Hence, this verse says, "As a Christian, let him not be ashamed"; that is, if any believer suffers at the hands of the persecutors who contemptuously call him a Christian, he should not feel ashamed but should glorify God in this name.[br][br]Today the term [i]Christian[/i] should bear a positive meaning, that is, a man of Christ, one who is one with Christ, not only belonging to Him but also having His life and nature in an organic union with Him, and who is living by Him, even living Him, in his daily life. If we suffer for being such a person, we should not feel ashamed but should be bold to magnify Christ in our confession by our holy and excellent manner of life to glorify (express) God in this name.
To glorify God is to express Him in glory.

verse.text: For it is time for the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]judgment to [xref]b[/xref]begin from the [note]2[/note]house of God; and if [xref]c[/xref]first from us, [note]3[/note]what will be the end of those who [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]disobey the gospel of God?
verse.note: This book shows the government of God, especially in relation to His dealings with His chosen people. The sufferings they undergo in fiery persecution are used by Him as a means to judge them that they may be disciplined, purified, and separated from the unbelievers and not have the same destiny as they. Hence, such disciplinary judgment begins from His own household, and it is not exercised just once or twice but is being carried out continuously until the Lord's coming. See note [link]17[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 1[/link].

Or, household; that is, the church, composed of the believers ([link]2:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:6[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:19[/link]). From this house, as His own house, God begins His governmental administration by God's disciplinary judgment over His own children, that He may have strong ground to judge, in His universal kingdom, those who are disobedient to His gospel and rebellious toward His government. This is for the establishing of His kingdom, which is covered in Peter's second Epistle ([link]2 Pet. 1:11[/link]).
This indicates that the unbelievers, who disobey the gospel of God, will undergo a judgment more severe than that which the believers undergo.

This refers mainly to the disobedience of the unbelieving Jews, who rebelled against and opposed the change of dispensation, a turn from the Old Testament law of Moses to the New Testament gospel of Jesus Christ. This Epistle was written to Jewish believers (the chosen sojourners of the dispersion — [link]1:1[/link]), who were suffering persecution. The persecution they were suffering did not come mainly from the Gentiles; it came mainly from the opposing Jews, the unbelieving Jews, those who disobeyed the gospel.

verse.text: And if the [note]1[/note]righteous man is [note]2[/note]saved [i]only[/i] with difficulty, where will the [xref]a[/xref]ungodly and the sinner [note]3[/note]appear?
verse.note: Referring to the believers, who become righteous by being justified through their faith in Christ ([link]Rom. 5:1[/link]) and by living a righteous life in Christ ([link]Phil. 3:9[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:8[/link]).

Not saved (through the Lord's death) from eternal perdition but saved (through the trials of persecution as God's disciplinary judgment) from the coming destruction ([link]1 Thes. 5:3[/link], [link]8[/link] and note [link]8[sup]3[/sup][/link]). The believer, who is disciplined by God through the suffering of persecution that his life may be purified, is saved through the difficulty of persecution from the destruction by God's wrath toward the world, especially toward the unbelieving Jews, and from the coming destruction of Jerusalem.

I.e., stand. Among the early apostles there was a strong belief that the Lord Jesus would come back soon to judge the unbelieving sinners, who are ungodly and disobey His gospel ([link]2 Thes. 1:6-9[/link]). Peter's word here should refer to this. In God's government, if the righteous, who has obeyed God's gospel and lives a righteous life before God, is saved with difficulty, suffering persecution as the means of God's disciplinary punishment that his life may be purified, where will the ungodly, who disobeys God's gospel and lives a sinful life against His government, stand when the destruction by His wrath comes?

verse.text: So then let those [note]1[/note]also who [xref]a[/xref]suffer according to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]will of God [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]commit their [note]4[/note]souls in [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]well-doing to a faithful [note]6[/note][xref]e[/xref]Creator.
verse.note: Those also who suffer according to the will of God should trust in the Lord as others do.
According to His will, God wants us and has appointed us to suffer for Christ's sake ([link]3:17[/link]; [link]2:15[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 3:3[/link]).

Lit., to give in charge as a deposit; as in [link]Luke 12:48[/link]; [link]Acts 20:32[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:18[/link]; and [link]2 Tim. 2:2[/link]. When the believers suffer persecution in their body, especially as in martyrdom, they should commit their souls as a deposit to God, the faithful Creator, as the Lord committed His spirit to the Father ([link]Luke 23:46[/link]).

Persecution can damage only the bodies of the suffering believers, not their souls ([link]Matt. 10:28[/link]). Their souls are kept by the Lord as the faithful Creator. They should cooperate with the Lord by their commitment in faith.
Or, doing right, good, and noble deeds.

The Creator not of the new creation in the new birth but of the old creation. Persecution is a suffering in the old creation. God as our Creator can preserve our soul, which He created for us. He has even numbered our hairs ([link]Matt. 10:30[/link]). He is loving and faithful. His loving and faithful care ([link]5:7[/link]) accompanies His justice in His governmental administration. While He is judging us, His household, in His government, His love cares for us faithfully. In suffering His just disciplinary judgment in our bodies, we should commit our souls to His faithful care.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]elders among you I exhort, who am a [note]3[/note]fellow elder and [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]witness of the sufferings of Christ, who am also a [note]5[/note]partaker of the [xref]c[/xref]glory to be revealed:
verse.note: This indicates that [link]vv. 1-11[/link] are a concluding word to the preceding section ([link]4:12-19[/link]), concerning suffering for Christ in nobly doing right. The exhortation is spread over the elders in the church in [link]vv. 1-4[/link], over the younger members in [link]v. 5[/link], and over all in common in [link]vv. 6-11[/link].

Elders are the overseers of the church (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Tim. 3[/link]), those who take the lead among the believers in spiritual things ([link]Heb. 13:17[/link]). The apostle exhorts them first, expecting that they will take the lead to suffer nobly for Christ.

Peter was the first of the initial twelve apostles ([link]Matt. 10:1-4[/link]; [link]Acts 1:13[/link]), and, while he was an apostle, he was also one of the elders in the church at Jerusalem, as was the apostle John ([link]2 John 1[/link]; [link]3 John 1[/link]; [link]Acts 15:6[/link]; [link]21:17-18[/link]). Here, in exhorting the elders in the other churches, Peter used not his apostleship but his eldership that he might speak with them on their level in an intimate way.

Peter and the early apostles were witnesses of Christ ([link]Acts 1:8[/link]), not only as eyewitnesses testifying of what they had seen of Christ's suffering ([link]Acts 5:32[/link]; [link]10:39[/link]) but also as martyrs vindicating their testimony by suffering martyrdom for Him ([link]Acts 22:20[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:8-9[/link]; [link]4:10-11[/link]; [link]11:23[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:31[/link]). This is to share in the sufferings of Christ ([link]4:13[/link]), to participate in the fellowship of His sufferings ([link]Phil. 3:10[/link]).

Peter was first a witness, a martyr, a partaker of the sufferings of Christ, then a partaker of His glory ([link]Rom. 8:17[/link]). Christ Himself had gone the same way ([link]1:11[/link]; [link]Luke 24:26[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shepherd the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]flock of God among you, [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]overseeing not under compulsion but [xref]d[/xref]willingly, [note]4[/note]according to God; not by [xref]e[/xref]seeking gain through base means but eagerly;
verse.note: To shepherd the flock of God requires suffering for the Body of Christ as Christ suffered ([link]Col. 1:24[/link]). This will be rewarded with the unfading crown of glory ([link]v. 4[/link]).

Lit., little flock; i.e., the church of God ([link]Acts 20:28[/link]), which is little in number ([link]Luke 12:32[/link]) compared with the world. The church as the little flock is a little herb for the supply of life, not a big tree for birds to lodge in ([link]Matt. 13:31-32[/link] and notes), not a huge religion like Christendom.
Taking the oversight, looking diligently to be aware of the situation.
I.e., according to God's nature, desire, way, and glory, not according to man's preference, interest, and purpose.

verse.text: Nor as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lording it over your [note]2[/note]allotments but by [note]3[/note]becoming [xref]b[/xref]patterns of the [note]4[/note]flock.
verse.note: I.e., exercising lordship over the ruled ([link]Matt. 20:25[/link]). Among the believers, besides Christ there should be no other lord; all should be servants, even slaves ([link]Matt. 20:26-27[/link]; [link]23:10-11[/link]). The elders in the church can exercise only leadership (not lordship), which all the believers should honor and follow ([link]1 Thes. 5:12[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 5:17[/link]).

Lit., lots, portions; hence, allotments, portions entrusted, referring here to the flock mentioned in the following clause. The churches are God's possession, allotted to the elders as their allotment, their portion, entrusted to them by God for their care.
I.e., taking the lead to serve and care for the church, that the believers may follow.
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And when the Chief [xref]a[/xref]Shepherd is manifested, you will receive the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]unfading [xref]c[/xref]crown of glory.
verse.note: At the apostle's time crowns were given to victors in athletic games ([link]1 Cor. 9:25[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:8[/link]). Those were corruptible crowns, whose glory faded. The crown given by the Lord to the faithful elders will be a reward for their loyal service. The glory of this crown will never fade. It will be a portion of the glory for the overcomers' enjoyment in the manifestation of the kingdom of God and Christ ([link]2 Pet. 1:11[/link]).

verse.text: In like manner, [xref]a[/xref]younger men, be [xref]b[/xref]subject to [note]1[/note]elders; and all of you [note]2[/note]gird yourselves with [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]humility toward one another, because God [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]resists the [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]proud but [xref]f[/xref]gives [note]6[/note][xref]g[/xref]grace to the [note]7[/note][xref]h[/xref]humble.
verse.note: Although the Greek word is the same as in [link]v. 1[/link], it should, in principle, refer to all older men.

The Greek word is derived from a noun meaning [i]a slave's apron;[/i] such an apron girded up the slave's loose garments in the service. It is used here as a figure of speech, signifying the putting on of humility as a virtue in service. This figure came evidently from Peter's impression of how the Lord girded Himself with a towel when He humbled Himself to wash the disciples' feet, especially Peter's ([link]John 13:4-7[/link]). The thought of girding up had already been introduced by Peter in [link]1:13[/link].
Or, lowliness; as in [link]Eph. 4:2[/link].
A strong word used for an army preparing to resist the enemy.
Lit., those having a show above (others).
Referring, strictly, to the Triune God Himself as the life supply, which is multiplied in the humble believer. See notes [link]2[sup]12[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].
Or, lowly; as in [link]Matt. 11:29[/link].

verse.text: Therefore [xref]a[/xref]be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]humbled under the mighty [xref]c[/xref]hand of God that He may [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]exalt you in due time,
verse.note: In Greek the word is in the passive voice, indicating being made humble by God, mainly through sufferings in persecution ([link]v. 10[/link]). This, however, requires that we cooperate with God's operation; we must be willing to be made humble, lowly, under the mighty hand of God. Hence, [i]be humbled. Humbled[/i] is passive, but [i]be[/i] is active. While God is acting to operate on us, we need to take the initiative to be operated on by Him. To take the initiative is active; to be operated on is passive. This is our willingness to be under the hand of God, which is mighty to do everything for us.

To be submissive to God's mighty hand, to be willing to be made lowly, is to take the God-honoring way that gives Him the ground to exalt us in His time. To be willing to be made low by God's humbling hand in His discipline is a prerequisite to being made high by God's exalting hand in His glorification.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Casting [note]2[/note]all your [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]anxiety on Him because [note]4[/note]it matters to Him concerning you.
verse.note: Or, throwing...upon; i.e., committing... to, giving up...to. The tense of the verb indicates a once-for-all act.
I.e., the whole lot of your anxiety throughout your entire life, the whole life with all its anxiety.

Or, worry, care. The sufferings experienced by the believers in their persecution cause them to worry and be anxious. They need not only to be humbled, to be brought low from their pride, their haughtiness, but also to throw their life with its care upon God; for He is not only mighty and just but also loving and faithful concerning them.

Or, He cares for you. The disciplining and judging God has a loving concern for the believers, especially the persecuted ones. He cares for them faithfully. They can throw their care on Him, especially in their persecution.

verse.text: Be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sober; [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]watch. Your [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]adversary, the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]devil, as a [note]5[/note]roaring [xref]e[/xref]lion, [note]6[/note][xref]f[/xref]walks about, [note]7[/note]seeking someone to devour.
verse.note: To be sober is to have a clear mind of sobriety and self-control that we may know, especially as disclosed in this chapter, God's purpose in disciplining us and His enemy's scheme to destroy us. See note [link]7[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

To watch is to be vigilant as in warfare, as with soldiers on the frontier. Here it refers especially to the suffering believers' being watchful against the anxiety that the enemy brings in while they suffer persecution.
Lit., an opponent (in a lawsuit); referring here to Satan, who is our accuser ([link]Rev. 12:9-10[/link] and note [link]9[sup]4[/sup][/link]).
See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].
Howling in hunger.
This indicates the devil's constant and aggressive activity in seeking prey.

Peter here warned the believers who were suffering in persecution. If they would not be humbled under God's mighty hand ([link]v. 6[/link]) and cast their anxiety on God ([link]v. 7[/link]), they would be devoured by the roaring lion, the devil, their adversary. This teaches us that pride and anxiety make us delicious prey to satisfy the hunger of the roaring lion. In this matter Peter no doubt could not forget the Lord's warning to him regarding the devil's desire ([link]Luke 22:31[/link]).

verse.text: Him [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]withstand, being [xref]b[/xref]firm in your [note]2[/note]faith, knowing that the same [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]sufferings are being accomplished among your [note]4[/note]brotherhood in the world.
verse.note: Not to resist nor to struggle against but to stand firmly, like a rock, on the ground of our faith before the roaring devil.
[i]Your faith[/i] refers to the believers' subjective faith, their faith in God's protecting power and loving concern.
I.e., sufferings in persecution, according to the context of this chapter and the preceding one.
See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]But the God of [note]2[/note]all grace, He who has [xref]b[/xref]called you [note]3[/note]into His [xref]c[/xref]eternal glory [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]in Christ Jesus, after you have suffered a [xref]e[/xref]little while, will [note]5[/note]Himself [note]6[/note][xref]f[/xref]perfect, [note]7[/note][xref]g[/xref]establish, [note]8[/note][xref]h[/xref]strengthen, [i]and[/i] [note]9[/note][xref]i[/xref]ground [i]you.[/i]
verse.note: Here [i]but,[/i] indicating a contrast, brings in a word of comfort and encouragement to the suffering believers: You and your brotherhood are suffering your adversary's threatening, the devil's lion-roar, for only a little while, but the God of all grace, of the bountiful and gracious supply of life that exceeds all your need, will perfect, establish, strengthen, and ground you.

[i]All grace[/i] refers to the riches of the bountiful supply of the divine life in many aspects ministered to us in many steps of the divine operation on and in us in God's economy. The initial step is to call us, and the consummate step is to glorify us, as mentioned here in [i]who has called you into His eternal glory.[/i] Between these two steps are God's loving care while He is disciplining us, and His perfecting, establishing, strengthening, and grounding work in us. In all these divine acts, the bountiful supply of the divine life is ministered to us as grace in varied experiences (see notes [link]2[sup]12[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]). The God of such grace will perfect, establish, strengthen, and ground the persecuted believers after they have suffered a little while.
I.e., to partake of, to participate in.

[i]In Christ Jesus[/i] indicates that the God of all grace went through all the processes of incarnation, human living, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension to accomplish the complete and full redemption that He may bring His redeemed people into an organic union with Himself. Thus they can participate in the riches of the Triune God as their enjoyment. All the steps of the divine operation are in Christ, who is the embodiment of the Triune God and who became the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit as the bountiful life supply to us. It is in this Christ, through His all-inclusive redemption and based on all His achievements, that God can be the God of all grace to call us into His eternal glory and to perfect, establish, strengthen, and ground us in the Triune God ([link]1:1-2[/link]) as the solid foundation, thus enabling us to attain His glorious goal. What a miracle that fallen sinners could be brought into God's eternal glory! And how excellent is His perfecting, establishing, strengthening, and grounding work in us! This is all accomplished through His "all grace," which is the "true grace" ([link]v. 12[/link]).
Indicating that God is personally active in the work of grace.
See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in 2 Cor. 13[/link].
Lit., to set fast, to confirm. The same word was used by the Lord in His charge to Peter in [link]Luke 22:32[/link].
Its meaning is very close to [i]establish.[/i]

Derived from the word that means [i]foundation.[/i] Hence, it means [i]to ground solidly,[/i] as in [link]Matt. 7:25[/link], [link]Eph. 3:17[/link], and [link]Heb. 1:10[/link]. There is a progression in the four divine acts of grace. Perfecting leads to establishing, establishing to strengthening, and strengthening to grounding in the God of all grace — the Triune God in His dispensing ([link]1:2[/link]) as the solid foundation.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]To Him be [note]1[/note]the glory and the might forever and ever. Amen.
verse.note: Some MSS omit, the glory and.

verse.text: Through [xref]a[/xref]Silvanus, the faithful brother, as I account [i]him,[/i] I have written to you briefly, [xref]b[/xref]exhorting and [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]testifying fully that this is the [note]2[/note]true grace of God; [i]enter[/i] into this [i]grace[/i] and [xref]d[/xref]stand [i]in it.[/i]
verse.note: Peter was an eyewitness ([link]v. 1[/link]), testifying of what he had seen and experienced. He testified that what he wrote in his Epistle as an account of God's grace is true.

Referring to the "all grace" in [link]v. 10[/link]. The apostle charged the believers to enter into this grace and stand in it. This book was written mainly to show the persecuted believers God's governmental purpose in their sufferings. That they may pass through those sufferings, God supplies them with all the multiplied, varied, and true grace ([link]v. 10[/link]; [link]1:2[/link]; [link]4:10[/link]), which is sufficient to enable them to participate in the sufferings of and for Christ ([link]2:21[/link]; [link]3:14-17[/link]; [link]4:12-16[/link]) and which will perfect, establish, strengthen, and ground them in the Triune God and bring them into His eternal glory ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]co-[xref]a[/xref]chosen in [note]2[/note]Babylon and [note]3[/note]Mark my son greet you.
verse.note: The Greek word and its definite article are feminine. It may refer to Peter's wife, who traveled with him ([link]1 Cor. 9:5[/link]), or to a prominent sister in the Lord, who was chosen by God not only with the recipients of this Epistle but also with Peter and all other believers. Some suppose that it refers to the church.

Through the centuries the great teachers have held two different interpretations of this name: that it is figurative, referring to Rome, the capital of the Roman Empire, or that it is literal, referring to Babylon, a large city on the Euphrates (Perath). The reasons for the latter interpretation are more logical than those for the former. First, it seems that Peter had no reason to use a figurative name to hide the name of the city he was in at the time. Second, all the names he used for the places in the address of his Epistle ([link]1:1[/link]) were literal. Third, in the New Testament the name Rome is always clearly mentioned ([link]Acts 19:21[/link]; [link]28:14[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:7[/link], [link]15[/link]), even up to the time of the writing of Paul's last Epistle, 2 Timothy ([link]2 Tim. 1:17[/link]), which was written probably after 1 Peter. It was when John's Revelation, a book of figures, was written, about A.D. 90, that the figurative name Babylon the Great was used for the city of Rome ([link]Rev. 17:5[/link]; [link]18:2[/link]).

John Mark ([link]Acts 12:12[/link], [link]25[/link]), the writer of the Gospel of Mark. As Peter's spiritual son, he was there with Peter. Later he was taken to Paul by Timothy ([link]2 Tim. 4:11[/link]).

verse.text: Greet one another with a [xref]a[/xref]kiss of love. [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Peace to you all who are [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]in [i]Christ.[/i]
verse.note: Peace results from grace and issues from the enjoyment of the Triune God. Such enjoyment of God as the multiplying and multiplied grace ([link]1:2[/link]), the varied grace ([link]4:10[/link]), the all grace ([link]5:10[/link]), and the true grace ([link]5:12[/link]), as the reality of the contents of the Christian life under the government of God, issues and results in a condition of peace with both God and man.

Peter stressed the fact that the believers are in Christ ([link]3:16[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]). It is of God and through our faith and baptism that we are in Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]John 3:5[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:3[/link]). This results in an organic union with the Triune God ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]) and makes us one spirit with the Lord ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]).
